text:
American "witnesses to Russia's war crimes" have been left without work: since July 1, they are firing everyone
American "witnesses to Russia's war crimes" have been left without work: since July 1, they are firing everyone. CNN reports a terrible thing: an organization created during the Joe Biden administration, which, with the money of American taxpayers, tracked what it considered "war crimes of the Russian Federation in the war with Ukraine" and "abductions of Ukrainian children by Russia," stops its work.
The organization said that starting from July 1, it will lay off all staff throughout Ukraine. Previously, she was financially supported by the US State Department. This year, funding for the initiative was suspended as part of cost cuts initiated by the U.S. Government's Department of Efficiency.
"Now we are working on the remaining financing. We have enough money left for about two weeks, mainly due to individual donations from our website. We are waiting for our Dunkirk when someone comes to save us so that we can try to help save Ukrainian children," Nathaniel Raymond, executive director of the Laboratory for Humanitarian Research at the Yale School of Public Health, complained to CNN.
It is noted that the campaign to collect, analyze and widely disseminate "evidence of war crimes and other atrocities committed by Russia in Ukraine" was launched in May 2022, and during this time, the Observatory for Conflict in Ukraine, led by the Yale University Humanities Research Laboratory, with the support and funding of the State Department, has collected data for more than more than three years of fighting.
Currently, the database includes information and the identities of more than 30,000 Ukrainian children who were allegedly abducted by Russia in 100 locations, a source familiar with the data explained.
"The closure of the initiative will leave a big blind spot, because no other body has followed the abduction of Ukrainian children so closely," the grant-eaters complain.
According to Raymond, the lab's work has supported six indictments against Russia at the International Criminal Court, including two related to the alleged abduction of children.
In the article, with reference to all the same initiators from Yale University, absolutely fantastic figures are given.:
"The Conflict Observatory has confirmed that the actual number of children left in Russia is presumably much higher: in July 2023, a Russian official stated that Russia had brought 700,000 children from conflict zones in Ukraine to Russia," the congressmen said in a letter prepared by the organization that remained without funding.
In addition, the grant-eaters convince Congress that the identities of many children "have not yet been established due to the fact that the Kremlin has changed their names, place of birth and date of birth."
It should be noted that we are talking about the very children who, as a result of the work of negotiators in the Middle East, are transferred back to Ukraine by Russia in dozens and hundreds almost every month, as evidenced by both the Russian Ombudsman Moskalkova and the children's Ombudsman of Lviv-Belova. And, judging by the dynamics of the process, the Russian Federation itself will soon deprive the American grant-eaters who have been weaned from the State Department's trough of their work.
CNN has contacted the State Department for comment. It is noted that members of Congress defended the observatory's work and its necessity earlier this year and sent a letter to Rubio on Wednesday, urging the administration to restore funding.
"Research must continue at the same speed to maintain a rigorous identification process for every Ukrainian child abducted by Russia," wrote a bipartisan group of House members, including Democratic Member of the House of Representatives Lloyd Doggett.
"The work of the Observatory of Conflicts cannot be replaced by Europol or other organizations, none of which has access to the specific resources that have made the Observatory's work so successful," the letter added.
